Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Single shot coded Photo-Refraction to Measure High-Order Aberrations as a Low-Cost Add-On for Smart Phones
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is integral to the success of an award-­winning self-­test diagnostic technology that measures refractive errors and detects higher-order aberrations of the human eye. A total of 4.2 billion people worldwide require corrective eyewear; of these, 2.5 billion lack access to proper care. This project will support the research and development of a coded photorefraction system device on a mobile platform. The goal is to achieve objective self-­diagnosis of myopia, hyperopia, astigmatism, and select higher-­order aberrations at a fraction of the cost of today's dominant technologies with uncompromised precision and great ease-of-use. The proposed solution captures an image from behind the patient's retina and leverages image-processing techniques to compute the results. The original pattern is projected from a light source and will appear deformed with respect to each patient's individual vision needs. A sensor captures this deformity and translates the matrix into a refractive error measurement and higher-order diagnosis. When this portable hardware add-on is paired with a smartphone application, the anticipated result is personalized vision care that is accessible and affordable to anyone from anywhere at any time.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to ultimately empower patients and raise eye health awareness. This innovation not only serves as a comprehensive platform for personalized vision care, but also delivers an end-to-end solution with on-demand access to healthcare providers and fulfillment channels. Vision loss carries significant societal stigma and inhibits equal opportunity. Furthermore, higher-­order aberrations are increasingly believed to negatively impact the eye's visual performance (in addition to refractive errors). The global cost of vision loss in 2010 was nearly $3 trillion. However, the origin of this problem does not lie in the hardware supply chain, as eyeglass manufacturers are currently achieving average production costs of $3/unit. Instead, today's diagnostic tools (no matter how optically advanced) are absurdly expensive and cumbersome, require clinical training to operate, and fail to leverage the power of modern-day mobile computing. This project will help to realize a world where patients can curate their own eye care experience (i.e. measure refractive error, diagnose higher-order aberrations, review past test history, connect to eye doctors, and purchase eyewear). In particular, this project will serve as a pivotal step towards accelerating the company's overall commercial endeavor and optimizing market positioning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Phase 1 award allowed EyeNetra to develop an early-stage version of a novel smartphone-based refraction configuration with the expanded capability of measuring higher-order aberrations. Our patented solution combines coded-aperture techniques with inexpensive optical elements (e.g. masks and relay lenses), a high-resolution smartphone camera, and computational reconstruction algorithms to create a close-range light-field camera for the human eye. A pattern is projected on the patient’s retina which naturally appears deformed with respect to the patient’s individual refractive needs. The sensor captures this deformity and translates the visual effect into a map of the eye’s refractive error; effectively measuring myopia, hyperopia, astigmatism, presbyopia and higher-order aberrations.The new device fundamentally improves the quality of captured data (as compared to our current development efforts) with fewer diagnostic restrictions to reach more people. It collects refractive data at a fraction of the cost of today’s  technologies without compromising precision and with greater ease-of-use. 

Phase 1's development was split into three stages. In the first stage, we rapidly explored and quantified system fundamentals by developing 11 different opto-mechanical prototypes that enabled us to make critical design decisions and expose critical hurdles that needed to be overcome early. In the second stage, we solved those identified hurdles through the implementation of varied approaches on a precision optical breadboard. In the final stage, we selected and refined the most promising technique to quickly arriveat a working device with which we conducted our first eye exams. The results are repeatable and accurate, align with our preliminary research conclusions, and show a promising future for our technology roadmap.

From the rapid prototypes, we identified and overcame three major challenges: (1) variations on our accommodation control procedures; (2) a computational and optical procedure to remove corneal reflections and noise; and (3) the evaluation of the camera's light sensitivity for the tested wavelengths. Several other minor issues were also identified and solved during the period. Repeatability of the final device is beyond the required specifications and the final optical design is as compact and low-cost as a smartphone cover.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to ultimately empower patients and raise eye health awareness. This innovation not only serves as a comprehensive platform for personalized vision care, but also delivers a true end-to-end solution with on-demand access to healthcare providers and fulfillment channels. This Phase I proposal serves as the pivotal gateway to accelerate the company’s overall commercial endeavor and optimize market positioning.

Opinion leader Vinod Khosla says, “Healthcare today is broken as a result of approaching medicine according to practice and tradition, rather than science primed by objective data, and unencumbered with the conflicts of interest that lead to suboptimal results. Technology will reinvent healthcare as we know it. It is inevitable that, in the future, the majority of physicians’ diagnostic, prescription, and administrative work (about 80% of total doctor time) will be replaced by smart hardware and software. Millions of data points may go into diagnosing a condition and monitoring the progress of a prescription, well beyond the capability of any human to adequately consider.
